attributes.title: Lottery Wealth and Entrepreneurship in the Great American Desert

q1.value: Lottery Wealth and Entrepreneurship in the Great American Desert

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The project will use the 1901 Land Lottery to investigate the effect of wealth on the subsequent entrepreneurship of lottery winners, in particular their market participation, employment status, and home ownership status. I expect that winners of better land lots (i.e., those with relatively low draw numbers) are more likely to participate in market capitalism; e.g., purchasing land patents, being an employer or self-employed, and owning a home or farm free of mortgage. A large literature in economics demonstrates a the importance of wealth for entrepreneurship and interprets the relationship as evidence of liquidity constraints. Several studies show, for instance, that the probability of being self-employed increases when people receive windfall gains in the form of lottery winnings and inheritances.

q16.value: Consistent with the liquidity constraints hypothesis, I anticipate that winners of better land lots (i.e., those with relatively low draw numbers) were more likely than those with relatively higher draw numbers to purchase land from the federal government (H1), be an employer or self-employed (H2), own a home (H3) [without mortgage (H4)],and own a farm (H5). I expect winners of better land lots to be more likely to remain where they settled after the lottery (H6) and work as a farmer (H7). Conditional on employment, I expect winners of better land lots to be less likely to be unemployed (H8).

q17.value: I will use three different estimators for the treatment effect of draw number on the outcomes of interest: ordinary least squares (OLS) without covariates, lasso regression with covariates, and nonparametric estimation based on means (without covariates). I will use corresponding 95% confidence intervals to evaluate the hypotheses.

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

I will use corresponding 95% confidence intervals to evaluate the hypotheses.

attributes.title: Breaking Down Barriers to Naturalization for Low-Income Immigrants: The Impacts of Monetary Encouragements and Behavioral Nudges

q1.value: Breaking Down Barriers to Naturalization for Low-Income Immigrants: The Impacts of Monetary Encouragements and Behavioral Nudges

q2.value: Jens Hainmueller | David Laitin | Duncan Lawrence | Michael Hotard

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: NaturalizeNY is a public-private program operating in New York state that promotes naturalization among low-income legal permanent residents who are eligible to naturalize, but may face signi cant fi nancial barriers to do so. The program provides information on the naturalization process as well as naturalization application assistance through the Office for New Americans' network of Opportunity Centers (OCs) located around New York. During the fi rst year of the NaturalizeNY program, two pilot programs were tested to better understand the barriers of naturalization among the low-income immigrant population in New York. The pilot programs use monetary encouragements and behavioral nudges in an attempt to increase the naturalization rates among low-income immigrants. Eligible immigrants could register for the NaturalizeNY program by completing a registration tool that captures their basic demographic and immigration information. Eligible applicants were divided into two groups based on whether or not they appeared to qualify for the federal fee waiver program for naturalization. If a participant's household income is below 150% of the FPL or they receive MTBs, then the registration system informs them that they potentially qualify for a fee waiver from the federal government. Among this group, behavioral nudges such as letters, SMS, and emails were randomly assigned.  If a participant's household income is between 150% and 300% of the FPL and they do not receive MTBs, then the registration enters them into a lottery for a chance to receive a voucher that will pay the fee for their naturalization application. (This fee is normally $680.) The encouragements mirror existing policies and interventions commonly used by immigrant service providers, but as far as we know have never been systematically tested. The study has important implications for the allocation of resources by social service providers who are interested in assisting individuals to apply for social programs and benefi ts.

q16.value: The hypotheses to be tested are whether or not the behavioral or monetary encouragements nudges had an effect on the probability that someone completed their naturalization application. For the group of participants that appeared eligible for the federal fee waiver, one of five behavioral encouragements were randomly assigned: a letter, a letter and metro card, a letter and four SMS messages, a call to schedule an appointment, and an intensive treatment of a call, followed by four follow-up calls and an email and letter if contact was not established. There was also a control group that did not receive any additional behavioral encouragements beyond an initial notification that they might be eligible for a fee waiver after completing the program registration. For the group of participants that were not eligible for the federal fee waiver, a subset was randomly assigned a monetary encouragement of having their application fee paid for. The key outcome of interest is whether participants submitted their application for naturalization. Information on whether a participant applied for naturalization is collected via a follow-up check-in approximately five to six months after the treatment assignment.

q17.value: Because the study examines two distinct groups and treatments, a separate analysis will be performed on each group. The analysis for the nudge experiment in the fee waiver sample will use linear regression where the outcome variable yi is a binary variable of the participant's response to the question, "Did you submit your US citizenship application?", Nudge1 - Nudge5 are dummy variables for whether or not a participant was assigned a particular treatment (the reference category is the control group that received no nudge); X is a vector of control variables; and i is the error term. The analysis will be done without covariates and with a limited and an extensive covariate set. Robust standard errors will be used. For the analysis of the fee voucher experiment, we will use a standard local average treatment effect framework. We estimate the intention-to-treat-using a regression equation where the outcome variable yi is a binary variable of the participant's response to the question, "Did you submit your US citizenship application?"; WonLottery is a dummy variable for whether or not a participant won the voucher in the initial voucher lottery; X is a vector of control variables; and i is the error term. To estimate the local average treatment effect of receiving the voucher we will estimate a regression where yi is regressed on whether or not someone received a voucher. This will accommodate the non-compliance (in the cases that someone did not win a voucher in the first assignment, but subsequently received a voucher when the original voucher assignment went unredeemed) and estimate the local average treatment effects of the voucher. Robust standard errors will be used. Note that because the assignment of the remaining voucher was conducted randomly we expect the effect of the voucher to be similar in expectation regardless of whether we instrument for Voucher using WonLottery or not and instead just estimate the simple OLS. The analysis will be done without covariates and with a limited and an extensive covariate set. For complete details on the analysis specification, please refer to the pre-analysis plan.

q5.value: I gratefully acknowledge excellent research assistance from Blair Read.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This study is part of a series of experiments on strategic discrimination in politics. After running a short pilot of my prior pre-registration, I realized that it would be confusing to layer multiple treatments on top of each other. So, I subsequently ran just a resume audit experiment with 400 subjects evaluating 4 candidate profiles each. This study is a follow-up. The last study presented 4 highly qualified candidate profiles. This study will be identical, but it will present subjects with candidate profiles of mixed quality.

q16.value: 1. Female and black candidates will be evaluated as less “electable” than otherwise identical white male candidates.

q17.value: Subjects will view 4 candidate profiles, one at a time. Gender (m/f) and race (white/black) will be randomized within each profile. For each profile, subjects will be asked, “if this candidate ran for governor in your state, how electable would [he/she] be?” The four response choices are very electable, somewhat electable, somewhat unelectable, and very unelectable. I will evaluate my main hypothesis by comparing the average “electability” scores of white male candidates against otherwise identical white female, black male, and black female profiles. I will also compare the probability that a white male candidate is considered “very electable” with the probabilities that white female, black male, and black male candidates are considered “very electable.”

The last study presented 4 highly qualified candidate profiles. This study will be identical, but it will present subjects with candidate profiles of mixed quality.

I will evaluate my main hypothesis by comparing the average “electability” scores of white male candidates against otherwise identical white female, black male, and black female profiles. I will also compare the probability that a white male candidate is considered “very electable” with the probabilities that white female, black male, and black male candidates are considered “very electable.”

attributes.title: Contesting a Protector: Explaining Local Public Opposition to U.S. Military Bases Abroad

q1.value: Contesting a Protector: Explaining Local Public Opposition to U.S. Military Bases Abroad

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Why do foreign publics sometimes resist the presence of U.S. military bases in their communities and sometimes welcome them? With hundreds of U.S. overseas military bases subject to varying degrees of local antagonism, the question remains a pressing one. While the comparative literature on base contestation often makes implicit causal claims about factors that influence local public opinion and behavior, these claims have, to our knowledge, never been tested empirically using individual-level data. Based on an online survey experiment with residents of communities hosting U.S. military bases in South Korea and Japan, this study examines whether trigger events, disruption of the status quo, movement framing, and policy misalignment between central and local governments can explain opposition to local U.S. military presence.

q16.value: We hypothesize that trigger events, disruption of the status quo, movement framing, and policy misalignment between central and local governments influence can influence opposition to local U.S. military presence.

q17.value: We will conduct an online survey experiment targeting residents of communities hosting U.S. military bases in South Korea and Japan. The outcome is measured in terms of attitudes -- sympathy with social movements contesting the local base -- as well as behavior -- donating a portion of one’s compensation to an anti-base organization.

registration_responses.q1: Contesting a Protector: Explaining Local Public Opposition to U.S. Military Bases Abroad
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities

attributes.title: Up for Debate? Using Radio to Reduce Polarization and Increase Democratic Engagement in Niger

q1.value: Up for Debate? Using Radio to Reduce Polarization and Increase Democratic Engagement in Niger

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Discussion programs are increasingly common features on radio schedules, and are often produced by actors working to encourage multi-perspective dialogue and improve political engagement in fragile settings. In theory, such programming could capture audience attention through its conflictual, yet inclusive, framing, thereby stimulating engagement. Further, discussion programs might combat polarization, by fostering understanding of alternate viewpoints and demonstrating that political conflicts can be addressed through dialogue. Despite the growing popularity of such programs, evidence about their impact is lacking; evaluations are typically limited to measures of audience size and the public's recognition of programming. This project will seek to identify the impact of two discussion-based programs in Niger--one centered on call-ins and the other on in-studio discussions by experts--through a field experiment utilizing a modified symmetric encouragement design, in which a subset of subjects is regularly incentivized to listen to a call-in program, another subset to an in-studio discussion program broadcast at the same time, and a third group is assigned to a control condition. Subjects' political knowledge, engagement, perceptions of internal efficacy, support for institutions that foster accountability, attitudes towards out-groups, and attitudinal moderation will be measured at a pre-treatment baseline, and again after a six-week encouragement phase. The theorized benefits of discussion programs are especially needed in Niger, which is marked by very low levels of human development; limited public engagement in politics; high levels of ethnic, partisan, and religious polarization; and the territorial presence of violent extremist groups, such as Boko Haram and Jama'at Nusrat al-Islam wal-Muslimin.

q16.value: Exposure to radio-based discussion programs will increase political knowledge, engagement, internal efficacy, and support for institutions of accountability, and will result in greater attitudinal moderation and tolerance of out-groups.

q17.value: Measures of outcomes of interest will be collected in a pre-treatment baseline survey, and repeated at a post-treatment endline. Differences-in-differences analyses will be conducted to compare changes in outcomes of interest between treatment categories.

attributes.title: International Public Support for Self-Determination Groups: Exploring Support for Different Tactics

q1.value: International Public Support for Self-Determination Groups: Exploring Support for Different Tactics

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Legitimacy and self-determination have received attention from international relations scholars in recent years, yet little research has examined these topics in the context of public opinion. More specifically, no extant literature considers how various violent or nonviolent strategies employed by self-determination groups influence attitudes and policy preferences regarding these groups. We contend that this deserves attention for at least two reasons. First, public opinion has the potential to influence the success or failure of actions targeting the state. Second, public opinion can influence the policies that states pursue. Through an original survey experiment, our project investigates how tactics used by self-determination groups influence external public opinion.

q16.value: We ask survey participants to read a short “news story” (constructed by the authors) about potential ceasefire accords between a self-determination group (the Donetsk People’s Republic) and a state government (Ukraine). We experimentally manipulate the types of tactics used by the self-determination group (i.e. violent or nonviolent tactics) to determine how various tactics influence support for the self–determination group. In total, there are six treatment groups and one control group. Participants are randomly assigned to one of the following treatments: (1) control, (2) elections within the group, (3) stone throwing, (4) terrorism, (5) demonstrations, (6) nonviolent interventions, and (7) social noncooperation. The “news story” each group receives is identical, which the exception of the tactic used by the self-determination group. In the control group, no mention of tactics is included. After reading the “news story” participants answer the first set of dependent variable questions. These questions are designed to assess participant attitudes towards the self-determination group and its members and the official state government. We predict that participants will show greater support for group employing nonviolent tactics, as opposed to no mention of tactics and compared to violent tactics. We next present participants with the second level of experimental manipulation. All participants read the same vignette describing how some international actors have condemned the self-determination efforts (US, EU, UN), whereas others have supported it (Russia). Participants then answer a second set of dependent variable questions, asking about potential US policy responses ranging from “doing nothing” to “sending US ground troops.” We predict that participants will show greater support for US involvement when SD groups have used nonviolent tactics as opposed to no mention of tactics and compared to violent tactics.

q17.value: The survey experiment will be administered online. It is programmed into the Qualtrics platform and individuals (18+) will be recruited with Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk). Participants are paid $0.75 to read a “new story” constructed by authors, answer the first round of dependent variable questions, read a second prompt, and answer the second round of dependent variables. We also collect demographic information and include attention check and manipulation check questions. There are 13 DVs in total. We will test the hypotheses with difference of means, logit, probit, ordered logit, ordered probit, and/or OLS models. Additionally, we will calculate predicted probabilities. We may also consider how political preferences (such as ideology and vote choice for 2016 US presidential election) and news consumption habits influence support.

attributes.title: The Political Determinants of Economic Exchange

q1.value: The Political Determinants of Economic Exchange

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: The role of political connections is not well understood in economic exchange. Existing work demonstrates the valuable benefits that political connections can bring to businesses. But in areas of the world where rule of law is not evenly distributed, those who have connections tend to receive preferential treatment in cases of contract breach. Why, then, would non-connected parties seek to do business with connected ones? And how do formal contracts affect this trust? I argue that there may in fact be a negative impact of political connections on business, moderated by access to formal contracts. To test this, I create a door-to-door sales business in Senegal, and hire traders who create political connections by working for municipal councils in Dakar. The traders then signal these connections while selling goods to households, while also offering formal contracts to certain households. Results will demonstrate the causal impact of political connection and formal contracts on economic exchange.

q16.value: The primary outcome will be the acceptance of the deal, coded in one of several ways. There are levels of the subscription, which corresponds to a scale from 0 to 3. I will also include two dichotomous codings of the outcome variable: one in which acceptance of any level of the deal is coded as 1 and refusal is coded as 0, and another in which a deal that requires trust (i.e., one in which the delivery of goods is made at a later date) is coded as 1. There are several hypotheses to be tested, listed in the pre-analysis plan. These include the direct and indirect effects of political connections, formal contracts that are required but free, and formal contract that are optional but for a small transaction cost. Hypotheses included in the pre-analysis plan also mention the interactive treatment effects between connections and contracts. Heterogeneous effects based on the buyer's baseline trust in political institutions, their own level of political connections, and other covariates are also included.

q17.value: I use a 2x3 factorial design, in which one dimension is the political connection signal, and the other is the type of contract available (if at all). These hypotheses will be tested using one-sided or two-sided tests, according to the direction of the hypotheses listed in the pre-analysis plan.

attributes.title: Effects of Public Health Messages about Zika

q1.value: Effects of Public Health Messages about Zika

q2.value: Victoria Chi | D.J. Flynn | Brendan Nyhan

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Public health depends on the widespread availability of accurate scientific information. The proliferation of conspiracy theories and other misinformation about health, medicine, and science have therefore created a significant challenge for public health officials. These theories often fill the void created by a lack of public understanding of a scientific or health issue and often persist and even gain credibility despite clear evidence to the contrary as they circulate in public discourse and through social networks. For instance, many people in Brazil --- the center of the current Zika epidemic --- seemingly do not understand the causes of the disease, the reasons for its spread, or the consequences it can have for people’s health. Rumors and unsupported reports have blamed the mosquito-borne disease and the resulting surge in microcephaly on genetically modified mosquitoes, on larvicides, and on prenatal vaccines. The spread of these conspiracy theories could threaten public health efforts to prevent Zika by dissuading people from protecting themselves against Zika, undermining efforts to enlist the public’s help in preventing the spread of the disease, and reducing support for responses to the outbreak by public health officials. Public health officials have employed a variety of messaging strategies to inform the public and counter these false beliefs. However, the effectiveness of realistic health messaging interventions addressing misperceptions have only been evaluated in a limited number of cases. How should public health officials respond? In this study, we will conduct a survey experiment with a large sample of Brazilian adults evaluating the effects of three types of public health messaging: a myths and facts approach to correcting misperceptions about Zika (debunking false claims about GMO mosquitos causing Zika and blaming larvicides and the TDAP vaccine for the increased incidence of microcephaly), instructions on how to protect oneself by preventing mosquito breeding in and around one’s home, and information on how Zika is spread by the Aedes aegypti mosquito. We estimate the effects of these messages, which we adapted directly from materials used by public health organizations (http://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=11661&Itemid=41735&lang=en http://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_view&gid=33071&Itemid=270&lang=en http://www.who.int/emergencies/zika-virus/articles/rumours/en/), on factual beliefs about Zika, opinions about different public policies that could prevent the spread of the disease, and self-reported intention to take steps to protect oneself from the disease. While each of these approaches could be effective, there are also reasons for concern. In particular, the myths and facts approach could be ineffective or counterproductive. First, the two-sided format used in a myths and facts approach may spur directionally motivated reasoning among people with a general tendency to endorse conspiracy theories or among people who believe in the specific misperceptions we present and refute; for these people, corrections may fail or even cause them to become more confident in their factual beliefs or policy opinions (Nyhan and Reifler 2014; Flynn, Nyhan, and Reifler 2017). Similarly, false information can in some cases produce a so-called continued influence or belief perseverance effect on people’s beliefs and opinions even after being debunked (e.g., Johnson et al. 1994, Thorson 2016). Finally, introducing false information can sometimes increase the familiarity of a false claim and thereby cause it to seem more plausible, especially over time as memory for the truth value of the claims fades (Schwarz et al. 2007, Berinsky 2015, Pluviano et al. N.d.). As a contrast, we test two communication approaches that could be more effective. First, we evaluate the effects of providing accurate information about the Aedes aegypti mosquito, the main carrier of Zika. During times of disease outbreaks, increasing awareness of the disease has been shown to be an effective method of causing behavior changes among susceptible populations that help lower the incidence of disease and prevent outbreaks from escalating (Funk et al. 2009). These effects are not limited to disease outbreaks; spreading awareness of endemic diseases can also lower disease prevalence (Funk, Gilad, and Jansen 2010). The same results may thus be expected when people are exposed to accurate information about Zika. By increasing people’s awareness of their susceptibility to the mosquito-born transmission, this information may help people better understand how Zika is spread, increase support for policies to reduce the risk of transmission by mosquitoes, and encourage people to take actions to reduce their vulnerability to the virus (Champion and Skinner 2008). In addition, providing accurate information about the way Zika is transmitted may be more effective at displacing false beliefs than denying their validity, which can be less effective if the denials do not provide an alternative causal account (Nyhan and Reifler 2015). We also test the effect of a message that instead encourages people to take specific steps to prevent mosquito breeding, a direct form of encouragement that might provide a cue to action for people to engage in protective health behaviors (Champion and Skinner 2008). In addition to increasing awareness of Zika, this type of messaging could help induce a sense of control and self-efficacy. Past studies have demonstrated that likelihood of conspiracy belief increases when people feel a lack of control (Whitson and Galinsky 2008; Sullivan, Landau, and Rothschild 2010). These findings suggest that increasing feelings of control through messaging that provides specific guidance on how to prevent disease spread could help mitigate conspiracy belief. (Our study design compares each of these approaches to a placebo condition that represents the no information baseline.)

q16.value: We will test the hypothesis that a myths and facts message reduces beliefs in myths about the Zika virus and increases accuracy of respondents’ beliefs about the true causes of Zika relative to a placebo condition both immediately (H1a) and after a delay (H1b). If this myths and facts message is effective at reducing belief in myths about GMO mosquitoes, larvicides, and TDAP, it should also have corresponding effects on support for these policies (H2) and increase respondents’ intention to protect themselves from the Aedes aegypti mosquito (H3). We will also consider whether the effects of the myths and facts message on belief in myths about the Zika virus relative to the placebo condition vary by respondents’ level of trust in governmental and health institutions (H4a) and their predisposition to believe in conspiracy theories (H4b). Our study will also consider the following research questions for which we have weaker theoretical priors. First, we will consider how the myths and facts message affects respondents’ policy opinions and intended behavior after a one-week delay (RQ1). Second, we will examine how the effects of the myths and facts message on policy opinions and intended behavior varies by respondents’ levels of trust and conspiracy predispositions both immediately and after a one-week delay (RQ2). Finally, we will test the effects of contrasting messages providing information about the Aedes aegypti mosquito and how to protect oneself from it on the outcome measures listed above in the first wave (RQ3).

q17.value: We will randomize participants into one of four conditions in a between-subjects design. Each treatment condition will be compared to the placebo (control) condition. We will also compare mean responses for each outcome measure between treatment conditions. In addition, the myths and facts condition will be compared to the placebo condition after a one-week delay. We will test the effectiveness of a myths and facts message about Zika versus the placebo condition on beliefs about Zika (both knowledge of how the disease is actually transmitted and belief in myths about the disease), support for policies to prevent its spread, and intention to engage in preventative and protective behaviors. We will contrast these effects with the effects of information about the mosquito that is the primary carrier of Zika as well as a behavioral message, testing their effects versus the placebo condition as well as versus the myths and facts condition directly. (See the statistical analysis section below for details.)
